item.title: Interesting way to do a blacklist
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:13, topic:416258”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=518196.msg3766199#msg3766199 date=1317255337]

I am aware of the 0.0.0.0 and 255.255.255 exceptions, or cases where all the bitnodes contain a active and non active bit. I cannot fix cases where all the nodes have the same amount of ones/zeros but I think I can fix the other cases. Its like debugging software, never done right the first time usually.

It’s not only 0.0.0.0 and 255.255.255.255; look at my test I posted.
I’ve already explained why you’re approach is naive and incorrect. Stop pretending it’s some minor bug in the way you implemented your algorithm. The flaw lies centrally in this whole delusion of your O(1) IP dictionary look-up.

Mmm I really don’t care frankly, you never learn from continued success so I take this with stride and maybe when I have the time I can figure out a way to make it better or fix it. Or possibly do what Method was suggesting and use a trie. Not really a delusion, thanks for the discussion.
[/quote]

It is indeed a delusion. You can expect is O(log N) (using a red-black tree, where N = the number of addresses in the dictionary), but that wouldn’t work well with entries that encompass whole ranges as opposed to single addresses. Using a radix trie like I suggested gives you worst-case constant time operations given constant maximum size (given that it’s upper-bound O(k) and k = 32 for IPv4), as well as optimal memory usage (via flattening unary subtrees). Your solution is broken because you don’t associate any context with bit state (which is associated in a trie, given a bit’s state is relative to its parent in the tree). De-repping me because you can’t admit your approach was naive is immature and pointless.[/quote]

Reputation is just a number, as you can see you made it up! The approach was an investigation, I was originally going to do a tree but could not think of a easy way to do so. Thanks for the interesting conversation I will be sure to look at that.

Read full topic
item.source: Interesting way to do a blacklist

item.title: Interesting way to do a blacklist
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:12, topic:416258”][quote author=veer link=topic=518196.msg3766166#msg3766166 date=1317253453]

I am aware of the 0.0.0.0 and 255.255.255 exceptions, or cases where all the bitnodes contain a active and non active bit. I cannot fix cases where all the nodes have the same amount of ones/zeros but I think I can fix the other cases. Its like debugging software, never done right the first time usually.

It’s not only 0.0.0.0 and 255.255.255.255; look at my test I posted.
I’ve already explained why you’re approach is naive and incorrect. Stop pretending it’s some minor bug in the way you implemented your algorithm. The flaw lies centrally in this whole delusion of your O(1) IP dictionary look-up.
[/quote]

Mmm I really don’t care frankly, you never learn from continued success so I take this with stride and maybe when I have the time I can figure out a way to make it better or fix it. Or possibly do what Method was suggesting and use a trie. Not really a delusion, thanks for the discussion.[/quote]

It is indeed a delusion. You can expect O(log N) (using a red-black tree, where N = the number of addresses in the dictionary), but that wouldn’t work well with entries that encompass whole ranges as opposed to single addresses. Using a radix trie like I suggested gives you worst-case constant time operations given constant maximum size (given that it’s upper-bound O(k) and k = 32 for IPv4), as well as optimal memory usage (via flattening unary subtrees). Your solution is broken because you don’t associate any context with bit state (which is associated in a trie, given a bit’s state is relative to its parent in the tree). De-repping me because you can’t admit your approach was naive is immature and pointless.

Read full topic

item.title: Interesting way to do a blacklist
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

I’m not saying my test throws an exception; I’m saying your code throws the wrong /kind/ of exception on ill-formed IPs.
That being said, your algorithm doesn’t work because you don’t understand how to implement the algorithm. Consider the case of adding 255.255.255.255 and 0.0.0.0 to the blacklist.
This activates all bits for “ones” as well as “zeroes”, meaning that therefore isListed() will return true for any valid IP passed to it.
You don’t associate any context with the state of a bit; e.g. the third octet of 192.168.0/24, while also seen in 255.255.0/24, aren’t necessarily equivalent to matching addresses.
Achieving constant-time for all operations is only possible here because you don’t actually implement a solution. Similarly, you can compress data down to 0 bits, but decompressing is going to be a hell of a lot harder.

Read full topic
item.source: Interesting way to do a blacklist

item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Laziness ftw lol, and they are most likely in an invalid format since I don’t have this problem. Now I have a very very slight logic problem that I did on paper, although I think the extreme case is rare the lesser is plausible. I have tested exactly what you have so I you can but I assure you it works.

Read full topic
item.source: Interesting way to do a blacklist

item.title: Interesting way to do a blacklist
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Radix tree

In computer science, a radix tree (also radix trie or compact prefix tree) is a data structure that represents a space-optimized trie in which each node that is the only child is merged with its parent. The result is that the number of children of every internal node is at most the radix r of the radix tree, where r is a positive integer and a power x of 2, having x ≥ 1. Unlike in regular tries, edges can be labeled with sequences of elements as well as single elements. This makes radix trees muc...

Besides, your algorithm doesn’t even work. Bit state is context-dependent, hence why you organize them in a tree (predecessors give these bits the context they need).

Proof of concept:

[code]import java.io.IOException;

import org.codeusa.omega.net.Blacklist;

class BlacklistTester {

static void test() throws IOException {
    Blacklist.addIP(Blacklist.toInteger("192.168.0.0"));
    Blacklist.addIP(Blacklist.toInteger("192.168.1.1"));
    assert !Blacklist.isListed(Blacklist.toInteger("192.168.0.1"));
}

public static void main(String[] argv) throws IOException {
    test();
}

}[/code]

D:\dev\scrap>java -ea BlacklistTest Exception in thread "main" java.lang.AssertionError at BlacklistTest.test(BlacklistTest.java:9) at BlacklistTest.main(BlacklistTest.java:13)

Is there any reason IOException is thrown by Blacklist.toInteger()? AFAIK the exception is not at all I/O related:

if(data.length != 4) throw new IOException("Invalid IP String : Data"+data.length);

Take a look at how the JDK does it:
http://download.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/net/InetAddress.html#getByAddress(byte[])

[b]Throws:[/b] [i]UnknownHostException[/i] - if IP address is of illegal length

Read full topic

item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

It works lol, I can explain it but I really don’t get what you are (if you are) trying to tell me.

The concept is practically: do you have an ip that has this bit at this position?

Funnily enough, makes sense that you would not be able to store 0.0.0.0 or 255.255.255.255 since that would conflict with checking patterns, possibly need to evaluate this more lol

item.title: Interesting way to do a blacklist
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I will explain when I am not on my phone, basically the way this works is that the nodes keep track of the amount of active/nonactive bits of each ip. Say you were to put:

0010

You wanted to check 0100

Since a active bit is not indexed in the 3rd position it will return false. The purpose of keeping track of the amount of indexed bits is so that if you need to remove the ip from the index, they can be reset if needed.

Read full topic
